newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: UBS sees EMU costing banks $7 bln per year.
newsitem.headline: UBS sees EMU costing banks $7 bln per year.

text.p: Union Bank of Switzerland said the global banking industry stands to lose around $7 billion a year in revenue as a result of Europe's new single currency.

"The single currency will undercut revenues, not only from forex trading, but also from money markets and bond markets, given lower and more stable interest rates," UBS said in the latest issue of its employee newspaper.
"In total, these factors could reduce overall industry revenue by about three percent or $7 billion per annum. The effect will be concentrated on banks with a high markets exposure," it added.
The report was based on findings from UBS's pan-European research team.
The euro project, set to start in 1999, will also boost costs as banks are forced to cope with a dual-currency system during the phasing-in period for economic and monetary union (EMU)
"EMU will also encourage innovation and cross-border competition, which will accelerate the restructuring of the entire financial sector," it said.
But many industrial sectors will benefit from the elimination of exchange-rate fluctutations under EMU, it added, especially companies based in what are now hard-currency countries.
It said this effect could boost earnings in the chemical sector, for instance, by up to 15 percent between 1998 and 2000 in EMU goes ahead as planned.
